supporting_text: The NAP emphasizes a One Health approach through coherent, comprehensive and integrated multi-sectoral cooperation and actions, as human, animal and environmental health are interconnected.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including setting up an integrated National Surveillance System of AMR in Sudan.
The NAP includes the establishment and implementation of an active and integrated AMR surveillance plan for animal, agriculture and environment sectors.
The NAP addresses environmental health by promoting good practices at all steps of production and processing of foods from animal and plant sources.
The NAP includes strategies for strengthening disease prevention and bio-security in animals, food, and agriculture.
The NAP outlines a monitoring and evaluation plan to track progress on its strategic objectives.
The NAP includes specific interventions with timelines for implementation.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes an operational plan and budget section detailing financial allocations for various strategies.
The NAP includes a budget section that assesses future financial needs for its activities.
The NAP mentions the establishment of a multisectorial AMR communication committee as a central coordinative body.
The NAP includes strategies to review and update policies and regulations on the use and access to antimicrobials.
The NAP includes initiatives to incorporate AMR and related topics as core components of health and veterinary professionals' education and training.
The NAP includes a comprehensive communication program for awareness and behavior change targeting various stakeholders.
The NAP acknowledges the role of WHO, FAO, and OIE in supporting the development of the plan.
The NAP includes the establishment of a National Surveillance System of AMR in Sudan.
The NAP emphasizes the need for a robust surveillance system to monitor emerging resistance.
The NAP includes strategies for infection prevention and control at national, state, and healthcare facility levels.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes the development of the National Essential Medicines List and Standard Treatment Guidelines.
The NAP emphasizes the need for regulations to ensure the rational use of antimicrobials.
The NAP promotes investment in AMR research activities.
